name: Cambridge Museum of Technology
description:
An old sewage pumphouse, with still-working steam pumps. Open on Sundays only, 2-5pm, and in winter, only the first one of the month. Occasional Steam days, plus other events. Small collection of ancient analytical equipment from Cambirdge Instruments, including an Electron Microanalyser- forerunner to the Electron Microscope. It's nerdy, it's ramshackle, it's clearly run with a lot of love and not much money. I'd call it a hidden gem, but you can see the shimmney from a long way away! Website is here (http://www.museumoftechnology.com/news.html)
Added by @Al__S

name: Cambridge University Museums
description:
A cluster of very nerdy oild-style academic musuems. Lots of near identical samples in glass cabinets with handwritten labels. Gradually becoming more "accesible", but doubt they'lll ever be anything less than nerdy. The Museum of Zoology is, as you'd expect, stuffed full of animals stuffed full. 
Website (http://www.cam.ac.uk/museums/)

name: Imperial War Museum Duxford
description:
Huge collection of (mainly military) planes. Houses a pre-production (and definitely not prototype, oh no, they don't like you calling it that!) Concorde full of test equipment. American hanger has an SR-71 Blackbird. End hanger is full of ground vehicles (tanks!). Large number of operational aircraft- planes fly most days, including Spitfires (multiple). Some hangers very polished, very professional, but operational ones populated by old men in oil stained boiler suits
Website (http://duxford.iwm.org.uk/)

name: Dunwich: a town swallowed by the sea
description:
Formerly the 'Capital of East Anglia' (c. 1500) this Suffolk town was one of the most important UK sea ports. It was in the top 10 'largest places in England' and had a population of 3000. 

However, it has rapidly fallen into the sea (and continues to do so) with only a handful of houses and 120 residents remaining. Notable places to visit currently include the museum and 17th century traditional pub.

Is a fascinating place to visit, so I would recommend going before it's all gone!

name: Collectors World
description:
With rooms dedicated to Lord Nelson, Dickens, the 1960s and Dame Barbara Cartland, the unexpected is around every corner at the Collectors World of Eric St John Foti.

This museum with a difference is just outside the town of Downham Market in Norfolk. 

Eric St John Foti has packed a remarkable amount into his 75 years. He has been a lawyer, an actor, an inventor and a hat designer, but collecting is his passion.

A life's work 


Eric St John Foti 
"Collecting shouldn't just be a question of amassing different objects," Eric enthused. 

"Everything you see here is part of my life, or has been part of my life. I have never thrown anything away, and it shows of course!" 

The Nelson Room looks at the life of the Norfolk-born hero who went to school in Downham Market.

For the more romantic visitor the Pink Room houses the world's largest collection of Barbara Cartland memorabilia. 

Eric never threw away his old television sets, radios or LPs - so he turned the whole lot into a 60s room that includes a special tribute to Freddie and the Dreamers.

Satisfied visitors


The Pink Room: click to see video 
As well as housing the only Armstrong Siddeley Car Museum open to the public, this must be the only museum where an old Concorde engine is under the same roof as a room dedicated to the actress Liza Goddard. 

Eric says the public are invariably amazed by the displays: 

"They all say, 'why haven't we heard about it before', and the great joy to me is of course that they say they loved it and they come back over and over again!" 

Visit The Collectors World of Eric St John Foti at: Hermitage Hall, Downham Market, 
Norfolk, PE38 0AU
t: 01366 383185

East Sussex BN3 7QA

name: Grave of James Prescott Joule
description: Joule died at home in Sale and is buried in Brooklands cemetery there. The gravestone is inscribed with the number "772.55", his climacteric 1878 measurement of the mechanical equivalent of heat, and with a quotation from the Gospel of John, "I must work the works of him that sent me, while it is day: the night cometh, when no man can work" (9:4). (from wikipedia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Prescott_Joule))

name: Milestones museum
description: After you've visited the shortest railway, cross the town to visit Milestones Living History museum http://www.hants.gov.uk/milestones

name: Deutsches Museum
description: Museum of technical and scientific artifacts, includes some fine examples of early computers, a camera obscura and a myriad of other instruments.

name: Centre of the Cell
description:
Working research laboratory with visitors' centre. The lab's nerdtastic design incorporates meeting rooms and furniture shaped like cells and organelles:

Blizard Building, 4 Newark Street, Whitechapel, London E12 AT

http://www.centreofthecell.org/

name: The Needles Battery
description:
The Battery is an old costal defence, built in the 1800s, which was used as part of Britain's space program to test the Black Knight and Black Arrow rockets from 1956–71 

http://www.theneedlesbattery.org.uk/

name: HSS Observatory
description:
Opening season: Normally Mid Sept - Mid-April, but we do vary this from year to year depending on the position & visibility of the bright planets. We will also occasionally open 'out of season' to cover such events as eclipses, transits and the unexpected arrival of bright comets.

Opening times: 8-10pm Friday and Saturday nights. 11am-1pm Sunday.

http://www.hampsteadscience.ac.uk/astro/observatory.html

name: Snuff Mills
description: Beautifully cared for by local conservation group. Walk along the River Frome as followed by Cromwell and his troops. Follow the river up to Oldbury Court or down into Bristol City Centre. If you are lucky you'll spot a kingfisher!

name: Foredown Tower
description:
A camera obscura in a former water tower. 

Foredown Rd
Portslade, Brighton
East Sussex 
BN41 2EW 
United Kingdom
01273 292 092

name: The Manchester Museum
description:
Good if you like taxidermy, and who doesnt?

The University of Manchester, Oxford Road, Manchester M13 9PL

http://www.museum.manchester.ac.uk/

name: RAF Air Defence Radar Museum
description:
This amazing and tardis like museum is run by volunteers, many of whom are former airmen with great stories to tell. 
Try your hand at backward writing for the ops room, and learn how to use the strings and weights on a triangulation table to figure out how far away your planes.

name: Barometer world
description: Sales, restoration, antiques, spare Parts - and to cap it all a museum! Just what the atmospheric pressure nerd in your life needs.

name: British Museum Station
description: Central Line Tube station situated between Holborn and Tottenham Court Road. No longer in use but still visible if you look hard enough out of the window...

name: Nottingham Transport Heritage Centre
description: big trains, little trains, mini trains, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nottingham_Transport_Heritage_Centre

name: Cresswell Crags - Earliest British Cave Art
description: Cave art from nearly 13,000 years ago, the only cave art from that period in the UK.

name: Imber
description: Suggested by @irregularshed. Village pinched from the villagers by the MoD in 1943 for training and never given back. Access is occasional (a few days a year).

name: Convex Weir
description: One of only three convex weirs in the UK.

name: Belshaw's Quarry Nature Reserve
description: An abandoned quarry full of limestone wonders! http://www.doeni.gov.uk/niea/nature_reserves/nature_reserves_belshaw.shtml

name: The Semiconductor Archives
description:
Very very very specialist shop- allegedly. No-one ever seems to go in or come out:

http://www.flickr.com/photos/55935853@N00/2980028351/

name: Bovington Tank Museum
description: It's a museum FULL OF TANKS. Not much more to say. @irregularshed went there 30 years ago and loved it.

name: Crich Stand War Memorial
description: A tower has stood here for over 300 years, the current one being built in 1849. Unusual for having a 'lighthouse' beacon that shines at night.

name: Royal Observer Corps Museum, Newhaven Fort
description: View a reconstruction of an underground monitoring post, which would have been staffed by volunteers from the ROC at the time of a nuclear attack. This museum gives a first-hand account of the ROC's responsibility during the 'transition to war' as it has been lovingly put together by members of the ROC Association. Includes telecoms for early warning messages, bomb power indicators, vertical Perspex maps for tracing the spread of nuclear plumes and tins of jam and corned beef hash to be eaten by survivors.

name: porthgain abandoned narrow guage mining railway
description:
Abandoned mining railway on dramatic coastline, goes right up to the cliffs, plus you can end up with very good fish and chips at Porthgain.


http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/southwest/nature/thingstodo/walks/allwalks/porthgain_abereiddi.shtml

name: Guy's Cliffe House
description: Ruined ancient house that burnt down. Dramatic views from The Saxon Mill pub (which really is a working Mill, with water wheel and mill pond)

name: Galloway Dark Sky Reserve
description: Nothing, just the vastness of space above you. One of the first world dark sky parks chosen for their absence of artificial light and their clear views of the Milky Way and beyond.

name: Aquarium, Fish Freezing plant and Fish restaurant
description:
An imaginative multi-function approach. What they don't freeze or fry you can watch swimming around in big tanks. Great collection of 'exotic' species such as haddock.

http://www.dingle-oceanworld.ie/

name: Carpetbagger Aviation Museum
description: http://www.harringtonmuseum.org.uk/WhatWeAre.htm

name: Peat Fired Power Station
description: One of the largest Peat fired power stations in the world. See the nearby land stripped for miles, with methane emissions warming the planet as this power station and its ilk make use of our 'natural resources'.

name: Cork Butter Museum
description: World's largest butter market and museum telling the complete story of butter.

name: Thwaite Mills
description:
Watermill Museum.
 
http://www.leeds.gov.uk/thwaitemills/Thwaite_Mills/About_Thwaite.aspx

name: Bell Labs, Murray, Hill New Jersey
description: Museum showing Bell Labs inventions, including the first transistor from 1948

name: Mells Iron Works
description:
Great old ironworks sites; abandoned houses and small factory buildings in narrow gorge with quaint stream - Great local geology stuff too... (see BGS)

Also bats.

http://www.bgs.ac.uk/mendips/localities/mells.html

name: Porthcurno Telegraphy Museum
description: A museum about the history of telegraphy at the site where the cables came onto shore.

name: Midland Railway Centre
description: Heritage railway line and centre, runs from Hammersmith to Ironville. Bridge runs over the reservoir, which is over the canal!

name: Murray Star Maze
description: Glorious pentagonal maze with tartan hedge pattern. Accompanying palace of Scone features albino peacocks and a collection of historic papier-maché vases.

name: The Hut of Shadows, Lochmaddy, North Uist.
description:
Hand-built stone and turf camera obscura on the lochside. Access by foot over suspension bridge.
http://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/1438241

name: Nikola Tesla Museum
description: Knowledgeable guides give you a half hour tour of a museum dedicated to the man who invented the 20th century. Includes a great demonstration of how Tesla used wireless electricity to light up a light bulb (this is the closest you will come to handling a light sabre).

name: Devil's Porridge Exhibition
description:
This amazing exhibition tells the story of the Greatest Munitions Factory on earth that was constructed on the Anglo-Scottish Border between Dornock in Scotland and Longtown in England.

http://devilsporridge.co.uk/

name: Belgrade Museum of Science & Technology
description: Eclectic collection of technological artifacts ranging from old bicycles to film projectors and from anchors to 1960s computers. Minimal labeling but great for spending a couple hours wallowing in the nerdiness of it all.

name: Second Highest Sand Dunes in Europe
description: Interesting sand dunes, the second highest in Europe apparently, with natural fresh-water springs coming from a perched limestone aquifer.

name: Historical Blast Furnace
description: Rare example of early blast furnace.

name: Heage Windmill
description: Working windmill.

name: Remains of windmill destroyed by Luddites
Anchor Church
description: A series of sandstone caves that have been carved into the rock. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchor_Church

name: Chislehurst Caves
description:
Huge network of tunnels used as an air raid shelter in WWII, entertainingly cheesy tours, great fun. Entertainingly cheesy website too:
http://www.chislehurst-caves.co.uk/

name: Mulberry Harbour Segment
description: Another bit of bonus concrete.

name: North Gare
description: A spectacular combination of nature and industry. Plenty of wild life and industry on a scale that is jaw dropping. It manages to be desolate and beautiful all in one go. You might see a few kite surfers off the beach.

name: Dorset Cursus
description:
10km long neolithic earthwork, this area is Longbarrow Central:

http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=1377

name: Museum Vrolik
description:
Pathology museum mentioned rather a lot in Armand Marie Leroi's 'Mutants'.

Faculty of Medicine, Academic Medical Center (AMC), Meibergdreef 15, 1105 AZ Amsterdam

http://www.english.uva.nl/about_the_uva/object.cfm/5A9B26F2-4650-4F28-9C25AEACA84713A0

name: Severn Bore
description: The world's second largest tidal bore - a single wave that rushes up the river when the tidal conditions are right.  Check timetables online, and go for 4-star or 5-star (for 5-start, preferably late evening or early morning, when there'll be fewer people)

name: The Monument
description: This famous memorial of the Great Fire of London is nerdy because it doubles up as a huge scientific instrument.  The central shaft is a zenith telescope and connects to an underground laboratory, and the steps are precise measurements to aid in barometric pressure studies.

name: Armley Mills Industrial Museum
description:
Oh so many bits of old machinery to coo over.  Not much of it works/runs any more, but still you've got to love a lathe.

http://www.leeds.gov.uk/armleymills/

name: Schiehallion
description: A fantastic easy hill walk with spectacular views.  Nerdy significance: a groundbreaking 1774 experiment to estimate Newton's Gravitational constant G by measuring the deflection of a pendulum by the mass of the mountain to provide an estimate of the mean density of the Earth.  There's some signage near the bottom about the experiment.

name: Eyam plague village
description:
Village which voluntarily quarantined itself during the Great Plague (1665).  Records of deaths during this period have given rise to useful epidemiological data regarding plague, and genetic studies of current inhabitants show a gene mutation ("Delta 32") hypothesised to arise from differential survival rates and hypothesised to offer some protection against HIV/AIDS.

There is a small, volunteer-run and nerdy / odd museum in the village.

name: Five Rise Locks
description:
Five Rise Locks - Canal walk/bike ride with a cafe at the top, bonus :) http://www.bingley.org.uk/around/locks.htm

(you might want to push your bike up, and coming down could be hairy for those at the bottom)

name: Thackray Medical Museum
description:
Thackray medical museum: http://www.thackraymuseum.org/

One review on google says it was too gory, strangely this was a criticism.

name: Mills Observatory
description:
Britain's only full time public astronomical observatory.  Built in 1935 for the express purpose of promoting the public's undertsanding of science.

Mills Observatory (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mills_observatory)

name: Braefoot Point
description: World War I Coastal Battery (http://www.scotlandsplaces.gov.uk/search_item/index.php?service=RCAHMS&id=50887), with a nice view of the the oil terminal.  Some photos (http://www.flickr.com/photos/59694745@N03/sets/72157626294276132/).

name: Winspit Quarry
description: Filming location for Doctor Who, Blake's 7, etc. Interesting for geology nerds as well. Watch out for crumbling rocks especially after heavy rain.

name: St. Aldhelm's(Alban's?) Head
description: Old Norman chapel, memorial to the development of radar, Coastguard station, who are happy to explain their work to passing visitors.

name: Tyneham
description: "Ghost" village in the middle of military firing ranges. Slowly turning into a museum with many information plaques etc. Open during Range Open Days (mostly weekends and during the summer).

name: Crossness Pumping Station
description:
Amazing Victorian pumping station, home to the largest rotative (and working!) beam engines in the world.

Currently closed for restoration, due to re-open in 2011.

http://www.crossness.org.uk/

name: Gas Museum
description: http://www.gasmuseum.co.uk/

name: Alan Turing Memorial
description: A statue memorialising mathematician, groundbreaking computer scientist, wartime Enigma cryptanalyst and persecuted homosexual Alan Turing.  Cast in bronze, and seated in the very pleasant Sackville Street Gardens

name: Chislehurst Caves
description:
An ancient labyrinth of man-made tunnels covering over 6 hectares. Originally quarried for chalk and flint, they have since been a munitions dump and one of London's biggest deep air raid shelters - housing over 15,000 people during the Blitz. Guided tours only.

http://www.chislehurst-caves.co.uk/

name: Intech Science Centre
description: An excellent science centre with a planetarium. There are usually at least a couple of different shows in the planetarium each day.

name: Remains of a WW2 Radar Station
description: Remains of a 'Chain Home' Radar station. There are bunkers still standing, the ruins of the engine house, and foundations for other buildings and the radar towers. Unst Heritage Centre has info about the site.

name: Worlds Tallest hedge
description:
More of a Nerdy half hour but pretty incredible none the less. More than 30 metres tall and 500m long.
http://www.bonsai4me.com/AdvTech/ATBeechHedgeMeikleour.htm

name: Neptune's Staircase
description: Thomas Telford's amazing series of 8 locks raises boats 70 feet above sea level across 500 yards. Excellent views of Ben Nevis thrown in as an added bonus.

name: Museum of Transport Greater Manchester
description:
Buses, Trams, what's not to like.
http://www.gmts.co.uk/

name: Bovington Tank Museum
description: Fantastic tank museum, as in Military tanks, not fishtanks, watch out for the yearly Tankfest when they get the lot out, sometimes including the only remaining working Tiger tank.  Open during the week and offers rides on tracked vehicles and some great indoor exhibits.

name: Scapa Flow Vistor Centre and Naval Museum
description:
Lots of interesting WW2 naval stuff - they even have anti-submarine netting in the car park. 
http://www.scapaflow.co.uk/sfvc.htm

Lots of WW2 remains still making up the harbour too.

name: Remains of a WW2 radar station
description: A 'Chain Home' Station, with surviving bunkers and foundation of other buildings and radar towers. More info can be found from the Unst Heritage Centre.

name: Museum of Science and Industry
description:
Lots of functioning steam engines in the Power Hall.
http://www.mosi.org.uk/

name: Royal Mills
description:
Walk around these mills in Ancoats and you understand what the Prussian architect Friedrich Karl Schinkel felt in 1825, when he marvelled: "the enormous factory buildings are seven to eight storeys high...where three years ago there were only meadows"
http://www.manchester2002-uk.com/history/victorian/Victorian3.html

name: Haynes Car Museum
description: Quite small so don't make a special trip, but worth a look if you're in the area.

name: Victoria Station
description: Beautiful Edwardian station precinct; many original features remaining (ignore the ugly MEN Arena building). Creepy: this used to be the site of the Manchester Union Workhouse and its cemetry, and occasionally workers dig up old skulls and bones.

name: Abandoned Railway/train carriages
description: A few decaying trains and a section of abandoned track, info here: http://andyworthington.tumblr.com/post/3944697074/nerdmap-1-abandoned-railway-trains

name: Anita Street
description:
Late Victorian municipal housing development; was originally going to be named Sanitary Street, but the residents didn't like it and 'S' and 'ry' were dropped. When you are here, do also check out Victoria Square, the block at the eastern end of the street: the first example of municipal housing in Manchester.
http://www.manchester.gov.uk/info/511/conservation_areas/1216/ancoats_conservation_area/2

name: Keighley & Worth Valley Railway
description:
With the steam train through Bronte Country. Actually, this is is not nerdy, this is beautiful.
http://www.kwvr.co.uk/

name: Pompocali
description:
Pompocali - Well-preserved Roman earthworks. Hardcore geekery.
http://www.theaa.com/walks/bardsey-and-pompocali-421274

name: Bradwell Power Station
description: Now decommissioned, this nuclear power station was built in the 1950s and quietly dominates the surrounding rural landscape. Walk eastwards from here, along a lovely shell covered beach, past WW2 pill boxes and sunken barges (to prevent coastal erosion) until you reach the atmospheric 7th century St Peter's chapel. Nerds will relish this surreal journey backwards in time, from modern nuclear science to ancient spritualism.

name: Met Office
description:
Excellent opendays for nerds by nerds. Weather, climate(change), architecture. Nerd h(e)aven, 
http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/about-us/contact

name: RAF Cosford
description: The RAF museum-V bombers hanging from the roof, atomic bombs, cold war propaganda and all sorts http://www.rafmuseum.org.uk/cosford/. And its close to a village called Tong Havana!

name: Richard Arkwright cotton mill
description: Now converted into JCB Academy. Close to JCB World Headquarters-there's a shop in the entrance to the factory and a park too.

name: Bartlow Hills
description: Romano-British burial mounds - the largest is 45 feet tall. The largest round barrows in Britain.

name: Wandlebury Ring Iron Age Hill Fort
description: An Iron Age hill fort, also the site of some archaeological controversies (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wandlebury_Enigma). Claimed to be the true site of ancient Troy (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Where_Troy_Once_Stood) by some.

name: Lloyd George Museum
description:
Founder of the welfare state
"This is an opportunity to dress in Victorian costume, to play with period toys and to write on slate".
http://www.gwynedd.gov.uk/gwy_doc.asp?doc=13265&Language=1

name: Stuart Landsborough's Puzzling World
description:
A museum of optical illusions, an impossible leaning tower and an incredible 2 level great maze with 1.5km of passages.

www.puzzlingworld.co.nz (http://www.puzzlingworld.co.nz/)

name: Kelly Tarlton's Underwater World
description:
"The Antarctic Encounter is home to New Zealand’s only sub-Antarctic penguins, offering a rare opportunity to see the magnificent birds up close in their icy domain. A unique snowcat ride brings you within arms length of the 80-strong colony of King and Gentoo penguins to watch their playful antics on the snow and their elegant flight underwater.

A walkthrough replica of Captain Robert Falcon Scott’s Antarctic hut (established back in 1911), complete with authentic memorabilia offers a glimpse at what it was like to live 100 years ago in the coldest place on Earth."

www.kellytarltons.co.nz (http://www.kellytarltons.co.nz/)

name: Hastings Fisherman's Museum
description: Down by the old net huts and what remains of the fishing fleet is this wonderful museum in an old church, still used for christenings & baptisms. Houses a collection of photos, nets and ropes. Fascinating: www.hastingsfish.co.uk/museum.htm (http://www.hastingsfish.co.uk/museum.htm)

name: Tide Mills
description: A derelict village on the coast consisting of worker's cottages from the old Tide Mill. Inhabited from 1761 onwards, the Mill stopped in 1900 and it was condemned unfit for habitation in 1936. The last inhabitants were forcibly removed in 1939 amid concerns of frontline of fire.

name: science center NEMO
description: http://www.e-nemo.nl/en/

name: German Museum of Technology
description: http://www.sdtb.de/English.122.0.html

name: The Fauld Crater
description: This  huge crater  - the site of the world's biggest non nuclear explosion, was formed when an ammunition dump exploded in 1944

name: Speedwell Cavern
description: Underground cavern which you visit on a boat

name: Eyam - The Plague Village
description: A village which chose to isolate itself when plague was discovered there in 1665 rather than let the infection spread

name: Bressingham Steam Museum
description: Great little steam museum with several narrow gauge railways and one standard gauge, static displays, 1950's dodgems, gallopers, and Dad's Army sets & memorabilia.

name: Emley Moor Transmitting Station
description:
The tallest free standing building in the UK - the Emley Moor transmitting station
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emley_Moor_transmitting_station

name: The House in the Clouds
description: Built as a folley come water tower, the House in the Clouds is a landmark in Thorpeness. Also available as holiday accommodation.

name: Kew Bridge Steam Museum
description:
http://www.kbsm.org

Built in the 19th century to supply London with water, the museum is recognised as the most important historic site of the water supply industry in Britain.
(Department of Culture, Media and Sport, 1999)

Marvel at the world's largest collection of steam pumping engines, many of which you can see working every weekend. Be awed by the 90" engine, the largest working beam engine in the world. 

Ride on London's only steam railway every Sunday from April to October.
See how London's water supply has evolved from Roman times to the present day.

Kew Bridge Steam Museum is open every Tuesday to Sunday from 11:00 to 16:00 and is operated by an independent educational charity and run by volunteers.

name: Horniman Museum
description: Stuffed birds, strange musical instruments, feasome african masks

name: Ladybower, Derwent and Howden Reservoir
description:
Two villages were flooded to create the reservoirs and remains can be still be seen when the water level is low. 
Derwent Reservoir was alos used as a site for the RAF Dambusters to practice low-level flying in order to drop the bouncing bombs on German dams.
http://www.derbyshireuk.net/derwentvalley_reservoirs.html

name: Kew Bridge Steam Museum
description: http://http://www.kbsm.org

name: Kilnsea WWI sound mirror
description: http://www.andrewgrantham.co.uk/soundmirrors/locations/kilnsea/

name: Turbinia: World's Fastest Ship
description: Super awesome world's first steam turbine driven & fastest ship (c1894) in the Discovery Museum in Newcastle.

name: Castle Hill
description:
Crazy iron age hillfort overlooking Huddersfield. Well worth a look if you are randomly driving around Huddersfield's surrounding hills!

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castle_Hill,_Huddersfield

name: Science Gallery
description: A nerdtastic collision of science and art with new exhibitions every few weeks and a great cafe/bar. Well worth a visit.

name: Claymills Pumping Station
description:
http://www.claymills.org.uk/

Visit on a steaming day for

name: St. Mary's Abbey
description: St. Mary's Abbey is one of Dublin's best kept secrets. Founded in 1139, it was once the wealthiest Cistercian Abbey in Ireland. Today only two rooms remain - the Chapter House and the Slype.

name: Horsell Common sand pits
description: Not much to actually *see*, in the traditional sense, but this is where the Martians first land in HG Wells' War of the Worlds. Worth a pilgrimage if you're that way inclined.

name: The Kempton Great Engines Trust
description: Impressive stationary pumping engines from the 1920's - pinnacle of the technology, just before obsolescence! Steam days approx once a month - mesmerising to watch the giant engine in steam. Intriguing location - park under A316 flyover!

name: Solsbury Hill
description:
Site of awesome view, ancient hill fort and Peter Gabriel song.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solsbury_Hill

name: Energy World
description: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_World

name: Milton Keynes Museum
description:
Includes collection of telephones and switchboards as well as GPO & BT vehicles - http://www.connected-earth.com/Partnermuseums/MiltonKeynesMuseum/index.htm
Also a variety of archival material and artifacts from nearby Wolverton railway works
Main collection is a museum of Rural life.

name: 1838 Iron Girder Bridge by Robert Stephenson
description: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolverton_railway_works#Listed_structures

name: Railway Tunnel Vent
description: This is a railway tunnel vent in the middle of a housing estate in Leeds.

name: Tickford Bridge
description:
built in 1810 is the only Iron bridge in Britain that still carries main road traffic and is the oldest iron bridge in the world that is still in constant use.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tickford_Bridge

name: ROC No. 20 Group Cold War Bunker
description:
The Royal Observer Corps' No. 20 Group bunker is the only ROC Group bunker to be preserved in an operational condition, and is now open as a tourist attraction.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/York_Cold_War_Bunker

name: City Discovery Centre
description:
The City Discovery Centre informs and educates visitors about urban geography and new city planning; as well as the historical and natural heritage of Milton Keynes.
http://www.mkcdc.org.uk/index.htm

name: Singing Ringing Tree (Sculpture)
description:
The Singing Ringing Tree is a wind powered sound sculpture resembling a tree overlooking Burnley, in Lancashire.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singing_Ringing_Tree_(Panopticons)

name: Haslingden Halo (Sculpture)
description:
A 18m-diameter steel lattice structure, lit after dark by blue LEDs powered by a nearby wind-turbine.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panopticons#Haslingden_Halo

name: Jodrell Bank Observatory
description: http://www.jb.man.ac.uk/visitorcentre/

name: Tidemills
description:
A derelict village built around the 1761 tide mill. The mill was stopped in 1900 and the village was declared unfit for habitation in 1936, the last inhabitants being forcibly ejected in 1939.

Had its own railway station and windmill.

name: Hasting Fishermen's Museum
description: Down by the old net huts you'll find an old church, built in 1854 at the heart of the then thriving fishing industry. Used as a store by the military during WWII, it fell into disrepair and was saved in 1956 and turned into a museum, housing a great collection of pictures, nets and a fishing boat at the centre of it all. www.ohps.org.uk/fishermens_museum/ (http://www.ohps.org.uk/fishermens_museum/)

name: La Coupole V2 Bunker
description: http://www.lacoupole-france.com/en/default.asp

name: Welwyn Roman Baths
description: Roman baths in Welwyn (http://www.welhat.gov.uk/index.aspx?articleid=723) found under the A1(M).

name: St Albans Verulamium Museum
description: The Verulamium (http://www.stalbansmuseums.org.uk/Sites/Verulamium-Museum) is a Roman amphitheatre that you can walk all around. There's also the baths from a Roman villa and a great museum with lots of interesting artifacts.

name: Shaw's Corner home
description: George Bernard Shaw's home (http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-shawscorner).

name: Lapstone Zig Zag
description: Remains of old zig-zag railway up into Blue Mountains. Includes abandoned Lucasville Station. Also near the historic Knapsack bridge, visit the strange Victorian mineshaft - dug for unkown reasons...

name: Old Lapstone rail tunnel
description: Used to store chemical weapons during World War 1

name: The Duck Hole
description: The walk down follows an old donkey track. Find bits of coal that used to power a steam pump in Victoria times - used to pump water to Glenbrook lagoon as a water supply for Mountains trains

name: Pub, Drive In & Resevoir
description: Weird nerd culture mash-up here. A fake English pub, a fake American drive-in cinema and a fake lake.

name: Cockatoo Island
description: An abandoned ex-prison and dockyard. Now used as an unusal camp-site and for art-installation projects. Worth visitng just for the tunnels through solid rock.

name: Murray's Beach, Booderee NP
description: Intended as the site of Australia's nuclear power plant. Now part of Booderee National Park - part run by indigenous original owners of the land. Whole area is technically an independent territory, not part of NSW. Near by naval base intended as a port for the city of Canberra.

name: Warragamba Dam
description: A great big dam. Enough said really. Enjoy.

name: Nicholson Museum
description: Traditional museum - with MUMMIES! Occasionally has a special exhibition on (Australian) Mother's Day.

name: Seacliff Bridge
description:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_Cliff_Bridge
Worth a look

name: Cairngorm Mountain Railway
description:
Funicular Railway to 1097m above sea level

http://www.cairngormmountain.co.uk/see-do/funicular-railway

name: Parallel Roads – Glen Roy
description: Remnants of shorelines of a glacial lake, visible half way up the mountiain

name: National Space Centre
description:
Large space museum in Leicester with IMAX cinema.

http://www.spacecentre.co.uk

name: Abbey Pumping Station
description:
Sewage museum, featuring a massive beam-engine pump built to move sewage uphill in 1891.

http://www.leicester.gov.uk/your-council-services/lc/leicester-city-museums/museums/abbey-pumping-station/

name: Abbey Pumping Station
description:

Great little museum where you can see the famous Tom Puddings - the boats which  carried coal from the west yorkshire coal mines to Goole. And at weekends there's trips round Goole docks.

name: Sandtoft Trolleybus Museum

The world's largest collection of preserved trolleybuses!

description:
Built in 1813 by a group of local farmers, it's never stopped milling.
http://www.north-leverton-windmill.co.uk

description: Small hill with remains of a hillfort, and where beacon fires were lit to pass messages across the countryside

name: Ardeer Dynamite Factory

name: The Royal Institution
description: Founded in 1799, the Royal Institution is the oldest science communication organisation in the world, home of the first scientific laboratories in London and the site of the discovery of 10 chemical elements.

name: M4 Junction 13.5 for RAF Welford
description: http://www.secret-bases.co.uk/secret4.htm#welford

name: Cromford Mill
description: World's first successful water-powered cotton mill.

name: Westgate Museum, Winchester
description:
Housed in a fortified Medieval Gate House, the Westgate Museum houses a unique collection of pre-Imperial weights and measures. http://www.winchester.gov.uk/LeisureAndCulture/MuseumsAndGalleries/WestgateMuseum/ 
http://www.winchestermuseumcollections.org.uk (http://www.winchestermuseumcollections.org.uk/index.asp?page=summary&mwsquery={totopic}={weights%20and%20measures})

name: Cromarty Forth
description: It's full of oil rigs and related erections being built, refurbished and demolished.  Get the sleeper train to Inverness then bicycle up around here.

name: Tyneham
description:
Ghost village -- residents were evicted in WWII when the area was taken over for military training and never given back.  Nice short walk from here to the beach for a BBQ, too.

During the week it's closed for shelling, but open most weekends and all of August.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyneham

name: Lulworth Cove & Durdle Door
description: Bit of geology.  Concordant coastline and all that: boundaries between rock types run parallel to the short, creating these bizarre landforms.

name: Dawlish railway
description:
Best nerdy railway trip in Britain.  It goes right by the beach, and through lots of crazy little tunnels.

Make sure you sit on the left as you head west.

name: China Clay Pit
description:
"Wheal Martyn".  Not been since I was about 8, and I can't remember how much it was serious museum and how much it was for kids to run around.

I do remember there was a view point over an actual working modern china clay pit, plus lots of old industrial shit.

name: Electric Mountain
description: Underground hydro power station - lots of tunnels and machinery.

name: Snowdon Mountain Railway
description: All the fun of being on the top of a mountain without even having to put in the effort of climbing it: use the steam powered rack railway.

name: National Slate Museum
description: Massive old quarries and mines, with associated railways and industrial stuff.

name: Thinktank Digital Planetarium
description: The UK's most progressive digital dome, the UK's first purpose-built digital planetarium, and now one of the top 10 busiest small planetariums in the world! (http://www.thinktank.ac/planetarium)

name: Anatomy museum
description: http://www.afranceattraction.com/france-attractions-mp/anatomy-museum.htm

name: Fakenham Museum of Gas and Local History
description:
aka the Fakenham Gas Works, the only surviving town gasworks in England and Wales which as such is a Scheduled Ancient Monument.  The small museum comprises all equipment used for the manufacture of gas from coal: retorts, condenser, purifiers, meter and gasholder.

As well as all the machines and systems used to produced gas for the town from 1846 to 1965, the museum houses a small, eclectic local history collection and a brilliantly nerdy set of gas cookers and gas fires from throughout the ages.

name: Newington Armory
description: The old site for storing munitions in Sydney, is now a park of strange bunkers. There is also a narrow gauge rail that runs on the tracks that used to transport battleship shells. The train takes you into a cordoned off nature reserve. Exhibits, a cafe and also an outfit runs Segway tours. Also a frisbee 'golf' course.

name: Craven Lime Kilns
description: Old industrial site with lots of old mossy buildings, tunnels and waterways. Also bonus peregrines!

name: Atmospheric Road
description:
Dalkey Atmospheric Railway (1843-1854) was powered by a vacuum in a 15-inch pipe for the ascent to Dalkey. Speeds of up to 40 mph were achieved, and the return journey was by means of gravity. The vacuum tube fell short of the Dalkey station, and the train relied on momentum for the last stretch of the journey.

 
Barnhill Lawn, Dun Laoghaire, Co. Dublin, Ireland

name: Dinorwic Slate Quarry
description: Second largest slate quarry in the world. Disused since the 1960s. Fantastic rusting history.

name: Severn Bore
description:
http://www.severn-bore.co.uk/

The Severn Bore is one of Britain's few truly spectacular natural phenomena. It is a large surge wave that can be seen in the estuary of the River Severn, where the tidal range is the 2nd highest in the world, being as much as 50 feet (approx. 15.4m).

name: Chislehurst Caves
description: 22 miles of tunnels under suburban south London, originally a chalk and flint mine with druidic/Roman origins. More recent uses include a WW2 air raid shelter for 15000 Londoners, and a rock concert venue. Excellent guided tours with atmospheric kerosene lamps.

name: St Clement's Church
description: A pretty medieval church overshadowed by two absolutely enormous factories both less than 20 metres away that don't just look ugly, they smell and sound horrible too. File under "terrifying modernity". A very short day trip, this one.

name: Britain's 1st roundabout
description: The location of britain's first roundabout in the World's first Garden City!!

name: Severn Bore
description: http://www.severn-bore.co.uk/

name: Servern Bore
description: http://www.severn-bore.co.uk/

name: National Railway Museum
description: Ronseal

name: Plague exhibition
description: http://www.barleyhall.org.uk/content.asp?ID=17 Nice plague doctor's outfit.

name: York Castle Museum
description:
The best nerd bit is probably the history of household goods. Washing machine development FTW.
Also lots of old farm equipment, & everything York people never got round to throwing away.
Free entry to York locals with 'York card' (library card).

name: Bootham Park Hospital, AKA Yorkshire County Lunatic Asylum
description:
The last of the old County Lunatic Asylums still in use as a psych hospital.

Grounds have a public footpath through, wander in to look at the architecture.

Inside isn't *technically* open to the public, though walk confidently past the receptionist and turn down corridor to your right to see the only portrait of 'Sir Jeffery Dunstan Mayor of Garratt' (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_Garratt), the original boardroom with lots of interesting inscriptions, & some spectacularly OTT architecture, tiling & stained glass.

York County Lunatic Asylum was historically notorious for its poor conditions. The death of a Quaker from Leeds there led to the setting up of the York Retreat, with its pioneering 'moral treatment', a significant moment in the history of psychiatry.

The Retreat still exists, in its original buildings near the University of York. Also not open to the public, but the Quaker graveyard at the back is, with interesting dead people such as Seebohm Rowntree, whose 'Study of Poverty & Town Life' helped found the discipline of epidemiology.

Avoid admission, the female inpatient consultant psychiatrist is at least thirty years out of date in her practice, & the food is crap.

name: Death of John Woolman
description:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Woolman

John Woolman, early Quaker anti-slavery advocate, died here.

name: Yorkshire Philosophical Society
description:
YPS have all sorts of interesting talks here.
Schedule at: http://www.yorksphilsoc.org.uk/
The museum has some good Romans too.

name: York Observatory
description: Open to the public about Saturday lunchtimes.

name: Birthplace of John Snow
description:
John Snow, epidemiologist & anaesthesiologist, most famous for taking the handle off Broad Street pump to prevent a cholera epidemic, born here.

Today there's just a small plaque on a dull chain hotel wall. All Saints North Street church across the road, where he was baptised, gives a bit of a flavour of the squalid riverside slums Snow was born into though. Beware the rather scary Anglo-Catholics.

name: Midget submarines
description:
The remains of midget submarines at Aberlady Bay. These were used for RAF target practice at the end of WWII.

 
Obviously, consult tide tables before heading out.

 
See here (http://www.derelictplaces.co.uk/main/showthread.php?t=12093) for more information.

name: Muybridge Collection
description:
http://www.kingston.gov.uk/museum/muybridge/

Collection of images and artefacts from one of the pioneers of the moving image

name: Museum Of Scottish Lighthouses
description: fabulous collection of lighthouse glass lenses, guided tours of old lighthouse by old lighthouse keepers

name: Jeffrey's Mount Road Cutting
description: classic Open University geology field trip site, excellent examples of synclines & anticlines (also handy for the most excellent Tebay services)

name: Alderley Edge mines
description:
the mines under Alderley Edge were worked from the Bronze Age to early 20thC. They are now managed by Derbyshire Caving Club who organise open days twice a year, and can organise trips for groups by arrangement. There is a small museum of mine history, minerals & artefacts run by the caving club, open most Sundays 
http://www.derbyscc.org.uk/alderley/index.php

name: The London Sewing Machine Museum
description:
www.sewantique.com (http://www.sewantique.com)
Two large rooms above a sewing machine company: one crammed full of early domestic machines in a variety of shapes, sizes, designs and amounts of decoration; the other room is dedicated to a great range of specialised industrial machines dating from the XIX to mid-XX century.
The (free) museum is only open 3 hours a month: between 2 and 5 p.m. on the first Saturday.

name: Museum of Automata
description: The Grenoble Automaton Museum (http://www.museedesautomatesdegrenoble.fr/) is a private museum displaying a collection of mechanical toys, player pianos, barrel organs and puppets. Particularly good fun if you can understand French reasonably well: the guided tour includes a chance to play with some of the exhibits.

name: Gnome Magic
description:
I've never been, but the roadsign advertising 'Gnome Magic' at the next junction has retained its allure since childhood. The website does little to clear up the mystery, but it seems to consist of a garden with some gnomes in it.
 
www.gnomemagic.co.uk (http://www.gnomemagic.co.uk)

name: Vintage Wireless Museum
description:
Visit by appointment only
Rosendale Road,London, SE21 8DS 
www.bvwtm.org.uk

name: Drakelow Underground Factory
description:
Over 250,000 square feet of underground tunnels originally built during WWII as a shadow factory for Rover. During the Cold War it became RSG9 and later a RGHQ.


Getting tours now is quite difficult as it's used for Airsoft games, but the numerous hidden blast doors are quite impressive, and a walk over Kinver Edge is a lovely day out, too!


There are a number of entrances along Kingsford Lane, this pin marks one (on the south side) and a small parking area.
 
Official website (http://www.stokes277.freeserve.co.uk/)
Drakelow Tunnels on Wikipedia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drakelow_Tunnels)

name: Museum of Victorian Science
description: http://www.museumofvictorianscience.co.uk Amazing private collection of lab and scientific equipment (nearly all working). 2 hour talk on the history of it all with demonstrations. Breathtaking. Phone to book, number on website.

name: Great fossil hunting at Ravenscar
description: Very remote feeling village which was planned to be a seasiude destination to rival Whitby- sadly never took off. Difficult cliff path down to the beach, but when you get there, some of the best fossil hunting in the area. Park at the National Trust information centre to walk down (has ice lollies)

name: Dymchurch Martello Tower
description: One of several dotted along the coast, the one in Dymchurch village is English Heritage so you can inside and have a peek. When I was a kid I thought they were called Marshmallow towers - they do look a bit like them! If Marshmallows were made of stone. Anyway, a great nerdy thing to look at - good combo with the tiny railway, the nuclear power station and the sound mirrors. Hythe-Dungeness is one of the weirdest strips of coastline in Britain I reckon - in a good way!

name: Newgrange
description:
Megalithic Passage Tomb. Intact. You can go inside a tomb that is over 5000 years old (that's older than the pyramids). Don't forget your Fedora & bullwhip! Da da duh daaaa, Da dada. Da duh duh Daaaa Da duhduh DA DAAH!   
website ... http://www.knowth.com/newgrange.htm

name: Crich tramway museum
description: A surreal place where tram lovers come to spend their spare time and retirement working on trams from around the world. They've restored an entire village to serve as a Victorian tram stop. Take a tram trip up the hill and then meander back on foot through woodland and meadows that hide giant insects and monsters carved out of wood. There are sooooo many trams. http://www.tramway.co.uk/

name: Blackgang Chine
description:
http://www.blackgangchine.com
The Isle of Wight's oldest and most loved theme park!

Continually falling into the sea, endearingly tacky, they just don't make them like this anymore!

name: Time Machine, Funtington
description: Weird and wonderful collection of clocks. gagdets, toys, instruments that you can actually touch, fiddle with, and see how they work. http://www.clocktrust.com/

name: Rotherham, South Yorkshire S60 1DX
description: UK

name: RAF Holmpton Nuclear Bunker
description:
Address:
Rysome Lane, Holmpton, Withernsea HU19 2RG 01964 630208

Website:http://www.rafholmpton.com/

They do regular tours, and can even do private evening tours. There is a section of this bunker still active as part of the signalling corps and you get shown round by a very tall, very intimidating member of the RAF.

Lots of fun and well reccomended - MAKE SURE YOU CHECK THE WEBSITE FOR TOUR TIMES.

description: Their recently opened Advanced Storage Building has a real high-tech buzz.  See http://bit.ly/efzd8i for one account and links.

description:
http://www.tram.co.uk/

Brilliant fun, whatever the weather, with the typically wonderful and mildly eccentric over-excitement of the narrow-gauge enthusiast. Colyton (at the far end of the line) is also nerdy for its part in the Monmouth Rebellion.

name: 17470 Aulnay
description: Frankrike

name: Mills Observatory
description: The Mills Observatory in Dundee, Scotland, is the only full-time public astronomical observatory in the UK. Built in 1935, the observatory is classically styled in sandstone and has a distinctive 7m dome, which houses a Victorian refracting telescope, a small planetarium, and display areas. The dome is the only surviving observatory dome in the world made from papier-mâché.

name: Woudagemaal, steam-driven water pumping station in Lemmer, (the Netherlands)
description:
ir DF Woudagemaal 
Gemaalweg 8 
8531 PS Lemmer
The Woudagemaal is situated on the outskirts of Lemmer on the N359 (direction Balk) and is still used to keep Friesland dry on wet days.
http://www.woudagemaal.nl/

description:
Neolithic Tomb / standing stones. See

description: A beautiful pub built into a cliff face and several surrounding caves. An excellent, slightly historic, day out. Enjoy the rickety elevator ride down into the pub and then explore the caves on a full belly!

name: Diamond Light Source
description:
The Diamond Light Source is a synchrotron, which accelerates electrons around an enormous ring to produce x-rays.

A great place to visit, they offer fantastic guided tours a few times a year, operated by volunteers, usually scientists and engineers who are full of enthusiasm for everything they're showing you. Check the website to find out when the next tour is.

www.diamond.ac.uk

name: St Ives Museum
description:
St Ives Museum
Wheal Dream
St Ives
TR26 1PR



Admisson Charges
Adults: £2.00
Children - 5 to 16 years of age: 50p




 Opening Hours
 
Monday  to Friday - 10.00 am to 5.00 pm                             Saturday
10:00 am - 4:00 pm
Opening from Monday 18th April to Saturday 29th October


Museum Description
The museum, situated in the old fishing quarter of the town and overlooking St Ives Bay, contains many varied displays and collections relating to the St Ives locality. It is St Ives's best kept secret, so there is plenty for all ages to discover and learn.
We can cater for many subjects, mainly those which reflect the history of our town: Fishing, Railway, Seaside Holidays, Mining etc.  Slide taks and audio visual presentations can also be arranged, but prior notice is essential.
Activity sheets are available for three areas of the museum: - Fishing, Mining and Farming at a modest charge.  As St. Ives was famous for its cats, for both old and young alike, there are our museum cats and their freinds to Find For Fun (at the last count thirty four cats and four kittens!).
Displays include: - Agriculture, Archaeology, Cornish Kitchen, Fishing, Geology, Local History, Mining, Hain Steamship Company, R.N.L.I., Social History, Textiles, Tradesmen's Tools, Wreck and Rescue, War Memorabilia, Audio-visual presentations of local events and old photographs (copies of many may be purchased).

description: Zimbabwe

name: Thynghowe a Viking age assembly site
description:
Thynghowe is a Viking age assembly site in Birklands on the western edge of Sherwood Forest.
Within the woodlands surrounding Thynghowe there are features telling the stories of King Edwin of Northumbria, the royal hunting Forest, the estates of dukes and the lives of the people of this area over a period from the 7th century to World War II.

description: Larger, and historically more significant than Stonehenge, Stanton Drew stones are in a sheep field with an honesty box on the gate.  Worth a visit even though it certainly won't take all day.  Have lunch at the nearby Druid's Arms to see the related Cove in their beer garden, possibly a neolithic alter.

name: Strontian
description:
Both strontium and strontianite are named after Strontian, a village in Scotland near which the mineral was first discovered.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strontium

name: Machinations
description:
Machinations is a family owned visitor centre and cafe which was formed as an extension of the model making and toy design company Timberkits. The business has expanded and now has a wonderful new Playbarn on site.

Machinations was built as a tourist enterprise because of its lovely riverside location on the A470.  It is half way north to south as well as half way east to west in mid-Wales and within easy reach of wonderful walking and cycling. The front of the Old Village Hall was rebuilt and extended upwards and outwards to accomodate the new centre and a tower built beside it to house a big red moving dragon.

http://machinationswales.co.uk/

Machinations
Old Village Hall
Llanbrynmair
Powys
Wales
SY19 7AA
Tel. 01650 521 738

name: Swindon Museum of Computing
description:
The Museum of Computing is devoted to the history of computing and digital development. It was the first physical museum of it's kind in the UK dedicated to the history of computing. 

The Museum is not simply a repository of artefacts, but has active displays as well as providing a forum for the provision of lectures. There is a mixture of permanent and temporary displays, many exhibits of which have been loaned by companies and other collectors.The Museum is keen to show former products of commercial computer companies, and welcomes such offers.

http://www.museumofcomputing.org.uk/

The Museum of Computing
6-7 Theatre Square 
Swindon
SN1 1QN

name: chislehurst caves
description:
Although called caves, they are entirely man-made mines from chalk and flint. It became an underground city of some 15,000 inhabitants with electric lighting, a chapel and a hospital. In the 1960s, the caves were used as a music venue. David Bowie, Status Quo, Jimi Hendrix, The Rolling Stones and Pink Floyd all performed there.

http://www.chislehurst-caves.co.uk/

Kew Bridge Steam Musem

name: The Cow Palace
description: Surely one of the world's most OTT cow byres. Don't think you can go in, but a little distraction on your way to the beach.

name: Aberdeen Maritime Museum
description: Of interest to anyone with an interest in maritime-related subjects. www.aagm.co.uk

description:
Second World War 6" gun battery and light house. There is even a bird hide to look at the seagulls! 

Nerd Nirvana?

Showcasing more lawnmowers (and related trinkets) than you could possibly appreciate in one sitting, this museum is definitely worth the trip. Be sure to ask them to switch on the audio guide.

http://www.lawnmowerworld.co.uk/

name: Teylers Museum
description:
http://www.teylersmuseum.eu

Great collection of scientific instruments. Henrik Lorentz (of the Lorentz contraction) once curated this museum.

name: Hoogovens Museum of Industrial Heritage
description:
If you're into steel, then this is the place to be in the Netherlands. Situated just outside the industrial complex of the Tata Steel (Hoogovens/ Corus) steel works in IJmuiden, this museum has an impressive collection of relays, controls and general steel type stuff from the almost 100 years history of the plant. 

Visit the website (http://www.hoogovensmuseum.nl/?page_id=943) (in Dutch) for an impression of the collection.

description: the world's largest model railway in Hamburg, Germany (http://bit.ly/oNbXNu)

name: Goathland
description:
Aidensfield in Heartbeat TV series.
"Rail Trail" walk from Goathland to Grosmont approx 3 miles, runs along George Stephenson's original railway line route of 1836, Grosmont is 1952 style British Rail station and is home to the engine sheds where locomotives restoration in progress.
Can get steam train back to Goathland. 
Nerdy Nirvanna.

name: Corus steam train society IJmuiden
description:
Located at the back of the Hoogovensmuseum is a train station where every last Sunday of the month you can take a ride on one of the steam locomotives. You have to book in advance on their website (http://www.csy.nl/dienstregeling.php) (unfortunately only in Dutch), but if you call one of the numbers on the website during office hours (don't forget GMT+1) then someone will probably be able to help you.
 
Furthermore, you can visit the workshop of the steam train society, if you want to go to the trouble of getting a day pass to get access to the steel works. You will have to call one of the numbers on this page (http://www.csy.nl/werkplaats.php), otherwise they won't let you in the steel works. Don't forget to bring your passport because that will have the same result without exception. 
 
Entrance is free, but it is sporting to become a member of the society for 10euros (if only for a year) to help with the upkeep.

name: Hutton's Section
description:
the most famous Geological site in Edinburgh. Here it is evident that a slab of sedimentary rock has been torn away during the injection of the magma that now forms the Salisbury Crags dolerite sill. The remaining broken ends of the strata have rotated upwards as magma tried to force its way along a bedding plane. At the contact the dolerite was originally chilled to a glass, now devitrified. The crystal grain size increases steadily away from the contact. Towards the top of the sill a little way to the south-east there are rafts of sedimentary rock within the dolerite. Hutton's Section provides conclusive field evidence that the Salisbury Crags sill was formed from a magma that intruded into older layers of sedimentary rock. 

http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/undergraduate/field/holyrood/huttonsloc.html

name: Tyneham Ghost Village
description:
The village and 7,500 acres (30 km2) of surrounding heathland and chalk downland around the Purbeck Hills, were commandeered just before Christmas 1943 by the then War Office (now MoD) for use as firing ranges for training troops. 252 people were displaced.... in 1948 the Army placed a compulsory purchase order on the land and it has remained in use for military training ever since. Though littered with scrap used as targets, and subject to regular shelling, the land has become a haven for wildlife as it has been free from farming and development. In 1975, after complaints from tourists and locals, the Ministry of Defence began opening the village and footpaths across the ranges at weekends and throughout August. Source: Wikipedia.

More at
